AT LILLE, Printed by I. CHRYSOSTOME MALTE, at the good Pastor, 1686. With Priveledge.

div.head: THE TRANSLATOR TO THE READER,
div.p:
I Hear present thee with à peece, which has but just learn'd to speak à litle broaken English, however as à stranger I doubt not of thy one goodnesse but thou wilt excuse the trips he makes hear & there in his expression, and impute the faults which thou findest therin to the place that brought him forth, litle or no English being there spoaken, and the Printer à perfect stranger to our languadge, but as the designe was never to please thee with fine phrases, nor with Elegant speeches, so I intreat thee to accept therof, as intended purely to imforme thee in plaine termes with all the proceedings of the generall assembly of the Clergie of France lately assembled as thou wilt find by the severall dates & times therin mentioned; & wheras the french Hugonots that flock dayly into the Dominions of England and
Ireland, on accompt of Religion, are not wanting to foment heats & envey between the subjects of the one & the other Religion, adding still (to make their case the more lamentable) new fuell to the old fire, it being à receaved maxime, that ill will, never speaks well; & à story never loseth any thing by the carriadge; so I ludg'd for truth's sake, that 'twould be convenient to publish in our languadge the whole proceedings of the said Clergie of France against the Pretended Reformed, & by so doeing to informe our litle English world, how farr the Clergie of France was concern'd in the persecution (as they call it) of the Hugonots.

In the first place Courteous reader, I present thee vvith their proceedings in the assembly of 1682. at Paris, upon this point, under the title of A PASTORALL ADVERTISEMENT, by vvhich you vvill find, insteed of Crueltys, the most svveetest, the most tenderest, & the most kindest Invitation to the Pretended Reformed for their reunion, that euer vvas, being vvithout doubt, the dictates of the holy Ghost; and is indeed all the Rigour, that the Clergie did excercise at that time.

But this fatherly aduise of the Clergie of France being misrepresented to the people of the P. R. R. by their Ministers infuseing into the minds of those under their tuition à fresh supply of their old leven of Calumnie & scandall, interpreting, union to idolatry, peace to Paganissme, & Reconciliation to Anti-Christ, with other Barbarous Reflections, persuadeing their pupils, that wee believe strange Doctrine and hold principals truly Pagan, imputeing à number of Errors unto us for faith which wee utterly Renounce & Condemn; and to speake really I cannot blame the poore people (who know no better) to have à horrour against the Catholick faith, for on my conscience, if the Catholick Religion were such à bloody, Idolatrous & abominable Religion as they persuade the people it is, I would sooner choose to turne turk rather then Catholick, & follow Mahomet rather then Anti-Christ, Esteemeing it salfer to receave the Alcaron, rather then adore stocks & stones for Gods, as they with Impudence persuade the people wee do; by which means the Ignorant & the libertine are à Gog, and for morning & Evening
service they have this, that the Papists are Idolaters, that they Rob God of his honnour, that they sett the Creature aboue the Creator, that wee surpass the Pagans for number & sorts of Gods, nay our very hogs are infected with this Error, according to a harrangue which was held forth of late, I will not name the gentleman least à blush might Rise in his face, which would be more proper in his heart, by à true Repentance for that abuse not onely of himselfe & his Auditory, but of the Catholicks his neighbours & of the saints themselves, for whom he ought to have à Respect, in as much as they are the beloued of God & are in glorie with the father which is in heaven, & not by Rediculous Languadge unbecomeing à Prelat in the Pulpit, to affront heaven, before the face of heaven & Earth; who not content to Calumniate the saints by markeing them out for false Gods to men, but also to swine, as Saint ANTHONIE is there quoted to be the God of our pigs; oh! unchristian Expression, as un manerly said, as disloyally spoaken, did he not know that JAMES the seacond our dread soveraign was of the same faith with us, and that saying the Catholicks do adore false Gods, is to say the KING is an Idolater, for to scandalize the faith of the Church of Rome, is to scandalize the KING who makes profession of that faith; to say the Pope is Anti-Christ, is to say the KING is à follower of Anti-Christ, & he that scandalizeth the KING, is à scandall to the Church of England, which hath no head on earth but that KING whom they scandalize, & unto whom the law doth give the keays of the Church of England in that statute, which makes the KING head of the Church, next and imediate under Christ, as well in spirituall as temporall, according to the express words of the act & ten̄our of the oath of supremacie; but what do I speake of this, as if 'twas a new thing, for the KING & Church to be scandalized by such P—s, as calls Saint ANTHONY the God of our pigs: But to kennell that discourse with an other made not an age since by a gentleman of the same profession, whose whole sermon did nothing else but endeavour to prove that the Pope was Anti-Christ. Which in it selfe is so Ridicule, that far from haveing
the least ground in Scripture, he hath not so much as an act of Parliament it selfe to prove it by, & therfore to be throwne out of dores, as being neither law nor Gospell: for the whole Bible mentions but of one Anti-Christ to come, and his Daies will be short. Mat. 24.22. And unlesse those Daies had been Shortened, no flesh should be saved, but for the Elect the daies shall be short'ned. And his power is to endure but three years & a halfe, Revel. 13.5. and power was given it (the beast) to worke two & forty months. Which is Just three years & a halfe, agreeing with all the holy fathers who Interpreted, A time, times and halfe a time (so often mentioned in Daniel & the Revelations) to be three years & a halfe, a time one year, times two years & halfe a time, to be halfe a year, according to the above text. But that Anti-Christ, who is to be against Christ, & war against the Saints, should pray to Saints, & Contribute with all his force to carrie on the war against enemies to the name of JESUS-CHRIST as the Pope & his predecessors have done, or that wee were to have a Continuall succession of as many Anti-Christs as wee have had of Popes for above 1600. years, is what I find no authority for in the whole word of God.

This digression courteous Reader, being a litle out of our present road, let's returne to what concernes the ensueing treatise; which as I told thee before, is the whole proceedings of the Generall Assembly of the Clergie of France, against the Hugonots CONCERNING RELIGION. Except some few circular Letters, to all the Prelats of the Realme, the Catologue of Hereticall books which they condemn'd & some such proceedings which no ways concerns this purpose, all the Rest is exactly translated, as their advertisement to the Pretended Reformed, their speech to the king, their Complaint to the king, & of what it was they did complaine, by which yow will find they did not in the least desire the king to disturb or molest the Excercise of the P. R. Religion, nor so much, as pray him to Revoke any Edict whatever which tollerated the Excercise of their Religion, for that there was no Edict which gave them the priveledge to Calumniate
the Catholik Church & to impute erronius Doctrines unto us for faith, which wee utterly abominate and Condemn, & that the said abuse might be Remedied for the future was all they desired, in order wherunto the KING sets forth an Edict to that Effect as thou wilt find in the end of the book.

In 1682. They made their advertisement, & on the 14th. of July 1685. They made their complaint to the KING; on the 21th. of July 1685. They made their speeeh to the KING in takeing leave of his Majestie, & in August following the KING put forth his proclamation or Edict; but notwithstanding these proceedings of the Clergie & the said Edict of the KING (although thousands were by the grace of God therby converted) yet the Ministers did never the less persevere & Continue their Calumnies, even against the said Advertisement & Edict, upon. Which the KING disatisfied, at their disobedience, did on the 22th. of October following set forth an Edict prohibiting the Excercise of the P. R. Religion through out his dominions, Comanding the Ministers of the said P. R. Religion, that would not be Reconciled to depart his KINGdome within fifteen dayes, therby Recaleing all his subjects of the P. R. Religion home within 4. months, & forbiding any others of the said Religion to transport them selves or substance out of his Jurisdictions.

But as this Edict, is separate from the intent, which was onely to set forth how far the Clergie of France was Concern'd in the affaire of the Hugunots, & their proceedings therupon & no more, & this Edict being the sole act of the KING no ways therunto solicited by the Clergie, & in which they had no hand, I did not thinck my selfe oblidged to translate it, although I have given thee the breife contents therof. Comitting the whole to thy favourable Conjecture, shall abreviate, with desire & Instance that where faults have Escaped (as nature is fraill) to atribute the same to the weaknesse of the translator & omissions of the press, & not to that venerable assembly of the Clergie of France Composed of so great a number of Prelats, famous through out the world for their piety & learning; & to the end their labours may have their Effect in thee gentle Reader, & in all others who are devided from the unity of. Ephes: 4.5. One Faith without which the Apostle says 'tis imposible to please God, let us therefore dispose our selves in the Name of the Liveing God seriously to consider of
union, & insteed of cavilling disputes which creates heats & aversions & sets each party on the Rack of Invention how to widen the gap, let us I say, constantly & without ceaseing with pure intention & holy devotion pray, that God of his mercie may open the eyes of those that are out of the truth to see their Error, & let every one who desires to be of the true flocke of Christ devoutly pray, that if he be not in the Right way of faith which leads to heaven, that God by his grace may force our wills to believe in his one truth through JESUS-CHRIST our lord, unto which dear Reader say Amen; with him that is, thy.

div.head: A PASTORALL ADVERTISEMENT BY The Church of France Assembled at Paris by authority of the King; TO Those of the Pretended Reformed Religion for their Conversion, and Reconciliation, to the Catholick Church.
div.p:
IT is à long time, Most dear Brethren, that the whole Church of Christ is lamenting for you, & that this holy mother full of à Most holy & Most sincere tenderness for her Children, sees you with Extreame greife always à stray, as if you were lost in the frightfull solitude of Error, since by à wilfull schisme you seperated your selves from her Bosom, For as à true Mother how could she forget them she carried in her womb? or how could it be possible for this Church to thinck no more of you whom she loued so much, & so well, that your unthanckfullness; hinders you not from being of the number of her infants unto whom the poison of heresie has made odious,
the Catholick truths, & that the tempest occasion'd by the Revolt of Calvinisme has made forsake her holy & ancient doctrine of the true faith, snatching you unhappily from the center & head of Christian unity.

Behold, most dear Brethren, the subject of her tears, she complains bitterly, this desolated Mother, of this, that haveing mistaken the tenderness that she has for yow, yow have rent her bowells. She searches, she seeks, for you her stray'd Children, she recalls you as the Patridge doth her litle ones, she strives & forceth her selfe to gather yow under her wings, as the hen doth her chickins, she solicites yow, she intreats yow, she prays yow, to take your way to heaven as the Eagle doth her young; always pierced with liveing pains of à painfull labour, she endeavours, weak Infants, to regaine your love à seacond time, fully Resolued for this Effect to suffer all sorts of torments, untill that shee sees JESUS-CHRIST truly Rissen & renewed in your hearts.

'Tis in this prospect, that wee Archbishops, Bishops, & others deputed of the Clergie of France, whom the holy Ghost has Established for to governe the Church in which yow were brought forth, & who by a perpetuall succession, holds to this day the same faith, & occupie the same seats as the holy Prelats did, who brought the Christian Religion amongst our Gaules, come to seek yow; & by the function which wee Exercice of Ambassadors for JESUS-CHRIST, as if God himselfe by our mouth spake unto yow, wee exhort yow, and wee summon yow to tell us wherfore have you seperated your selves from us?

In the present state yow now are in, owne it, or owne it not, yow are in Effect our Brethren, honoured heartofore by our common father which is in heaven, with the title of his adopted, & brought up by the same mother which is the Church, in hopes to possess one day the inheritance design'd for her true Children.

And he himselfe that dared to seduce yow by his Error, & that perswaded yow to obey the truth no more, the head of your pretended Reforme, did he not live with us before his schisme as our Brother? did he not dwell in the same house of our father? did he not eat of the same spirituall food? did he not with us do the same offices, & acquit the same dutys of Christian Brother hood? Justifie, if you can before God your father, before the Church your Mother, before Catholicks your Brothers, the shame & Infamie
of a separation so criminall, so violent & so immoderate? do you Iustifie your selves of being devided from the body of JESUS-CHRIST; of being Retrench'd from the participation of the Sacraments of JESUS-CHRIST; of haveing made à cruell warr against the members of JESUS-CHRIST; of haveing vomited so much venome against the spouse of JESUS-CHRIST; & of haveing renounced to the promises of JESUS-CHRIST; Excuse this fault & wash of this spott if you can; & because you can never do it, confess that this Oracle of the scripture falls directly upon you; The Revolted Child says boldly his Conduct is Iust; but when one asks him wherfore he for sooke the house of his father, he cannot Justifie his goeing forth.

Wherfore Then, most dear Brethren, did yow not Remaine fixed to the root & center of the Church with the Rest of the houshold? hovv comes it that yow over threw the alters, & that in over throwing them, yow have broke the vou's and desires of all the faithfull? why did yow cut of the way of prayers which lead unto heaven? since 'twas from the feet of these Alters, the voices of Christians were elevated even to the throne of God; why then fearing that they should cōtinue sendeing the accustomed prayers to heaven have yow broaken downe this misterious lather, in overthrowing by your Sacrilegious hands, those sacred prayers which served as the basis & foundation therof; all other Sectaries that were before yow, were contented to Raise Alter against Alter; but yow, by an Enterprise of which the world did ignore untill your days, for to abolish entirely the Sacrifice of JESUS-CHRIST; yow have presum'd to demolish the Alters of the Lord of virtues where JESUS-CHRIST, the true shepheard, according to S. Augustin had chose his abode, & where the true doue, which according to the same father is the Church, had built her nest for the security & preservation of her litle ones.

But vvee vvill, that all this exces of vvhich vvee have spoke; & Generally all that has happen'd since your Revolt; vvhether of vvars against the Church, or of Errors against the Doctrine, has been the Effect of that furie vvhich ordinarily accompagnies all sorts of schismes; & that it ought rather to be atributed to the evill spirit of Revolt, then to any vvicked inclination of your parte; the Continuall & cheife complaint vvhich at all times vvee make against you, & upon vvich vvee at present
insist, is againe & allvvays to demand of you, Why did yow separate your selves from us? So long as you do not ansvver precisely to this question; vvhatever you may say or vvrite upon all other subjects, vvill be to no purpose.

Wee doubt not, but you vvill hear appply the old ansvver so familiar to all schismaticks; & knovving by Experience that 'tis impossible for you to shake the foundation of our beliefe, you vvill have recours to the spetious pretext of the disordered lives of severall people of our Religion; & that you vvil alleadge, that makeing profession to lead à life vvholy Reform'd & to follovv the most strict rules of Christianity, it vvas not beseeming your Reputations, nor salfe for your consciences, to Remain any longer amongst people of so Reproachfull behaviour? vvas this then, Most dear Brethren, the only motiff for vvhich yovv Iudg'd it lavvfull to breake the holy unity of Christianity, to Blaspheme against the heritadge of your Brethren, to Scoff at the truth & efficacie of the holy Sacraments of the church? Behold to vvhat à degree you are Remoued from the spirit of the Gospell: it's Certaine that if all th se crimes vvhich you object, vvere vvithout doubt, as perhaps not so many, & of less vveight, or perhaps vvere hidden, or altogether invented or Imaginarie, or grant that they vvere all reall, publick & aver'd, and that they vvere greater & vvorss then you say, yet good Christians ought to spare the cockle that grovvs amongst the vvheat in Consideration • f the good corne; because vvee are bound to beare vvith the frailties of our Brethren, to preserve comunion vvith the Just. Moses, had he recours to schisme, when so many thousands of men murmur'd against God; Samuell, had he Recours to schisme, when the sons of Hely &c. comitted such unworthy sacriledge; JESUS-CHRIST, had he recours to schisme, when he was sold to his enemies by Judas the theife, divill, & traitor; The Apostles, did they fall into schisme with their false Brethren & false Apostles enemies of them, and of their Doctrine? & Saint Paul who made it his businesse to forget his proper intrests, for the sake of those of JESUS-CHRIST, did he not always abide with an Extreame patience, amongst those who sacrificed the interests of JESUS-CHRIST to their unhappy lusts; & you, our most dear Brethren, you have not onely resolved not to
bear with the pretended defects of your Mother the Church & spouse of JESUS-CHRIST; but you must absent your selves from her comunion, dishonouring & disgraceing her throughout the whole world; & that you might Rent & divide her with the more Cruelty, yow have accused her of Blemishes vvherof she vvas vvholy innocent, & to be found onely in some fevv particular persons, not Considering that JESUS-CHRIST, hath cleans'd her in the pure vvaters of his Baptisme by the vvord of life, to the end Ephes. 5.27. That he might present it to himselfe a glorious Church, not haveing spot, or wrinckle, or any such thing, but that it Should be holy & without Blemish.

What is it novv, that Remains for us, most dear Brethren, if it be not to apply unto you the Councill of the holy Ghost: Math. 5.9. Blessed are the Peace-makers; for they shall be caled the children of God, and to conjure you by those bowells which you have rent; by the bosome of your dear Mother the Church, which you have forsaken; by the Brotherly love, which you have so often violated; by the Sacraments of JESUS-CHRIST which you have undervalved; by the Alters of the liveing God, which you have overthrowne; & finally by all that's most sacred & holy, in heaven & Earth, seriously to thinck of your amendment, of your returne & of your reconciliation with your Mother the Church, & what can there now Remaine for you, but to forget forever the schisme into which you are falen; to remember the infinite tendernesses of the Church which loves you so well, & out of hand to Returne to the house of your father; where mercenaries themselves do live in plenty, whilst you, stray'd by your Revolte into a desolate country without habitation, without pathes & without waters, find not so much as the least crum to sustaine you, in your languishment, against the spirituall hunger which Consumes & devoures you; why do you delay, & how comes it that you still Resist; is it that you are ashamed to Re-assume the qualitie of being sonns of the Church, whilst LOUIS THE GREAT; her Eldest son makes it his cheife glorie to raise dayly new tropheis to the honnour of à Mother so worthy; his happiness finds no limits but by your obstinacy only; seeing him
Erect dayly so many pious & holy Monuments to the advantadge of Christianity; the only thing that can be à troble to him, is to see such à number of his subjects, such enemies of his Religion & desertors of the Antient Christian Army, who not content to have broken downe the Alters of their fore fathers, to abandon themselves to an unknowne worship & to strange ceremonies, are still obstinate to Remaine in their first Errors this Great prince of late Exprest himselfe unto us, upon the desire he had for your Returne, after à manner which of it selfe would be suffitient to merrit him the name of most Christian, when he protested unto us, that he desired your Reunion to the Church with so great à heart, that he would Esteem himselfe happy to Contribute of his one blood, & with loss of his invincible Arme, with which he has subdved such numbers of his Enemies & gain'd such vast conquests. Oh, why then most dear Brethren, will you any longer hinder your King, after haveing vanquisht such dreadfull forces, taken so many stong places, subjected such great Provinces, & heap'd triumph upon triumph, to gather now this last palme which he Esteemes more then all the Rest

Againe, most dear Brethren when wee conjure you with so much Instance & that vvee Exhort you so tenderly, to give ear to the counsells of peace & of Reconciliation which wee give unto you; do not dear Brethren answer us & say: WHERFORE DO YOU SEEK VS? this Replie is the Languadge of that obstinacy which Retains you in the schisme; & not of Charity which makes Christians & Reunites them in one & the same society. Remember your selves that in seeking you wee do execute the order & will of the spirit of truth & of peace, who comands us by his prophete, to call upon those without ceaseing, who would not have us call them Brethren: YOU ARE OVR BRETHREN.

Oh, was there ever à time more proper to recall yow to the comunion of Rome then this in which the Church is governed by the Pope INNOCENT the XI. whose life & manners formed upon the most ancient & most severe rules of Christian discipline, makes apparent to the world in our days, a Modele of sanctity the most perfect? in such
sort, that you can never do any thing for your greater glorie, nor of more profit for your salvation then to reconcile your selves with this holy Pope, whose life is a schoole of all liveing virtues & perfections.

You then, poore diseased, who stand in such need of à Phisitian; you, members of JESUS-CHRIST, considerable to the truth; because you were redeem'd with the same blood as wee were; but unhappily seperated from the head & members of the Church by the dreadfull artifices of our common Enemie; permitt that the immortall hand of God may make you whole. Receave with one spirit and with one heart this fatherly advise, or if you pleas this instant pray • r; for such is our tendernesse & compassion for yow that wee thought fit to invite you after this manner. R'enter then, our most dear Brethren, by this favourable gate which Brotherly love hath open'd unto you in the be halfe of the Church; to the end that by the helpe of the all powerfull God, the thick clouds of your Errors being on'st dissipated, the light of truth may more & more manifest it selfe in you. Be not the occasion of the losse of so many poore souls, by the false Ideas of our belife, with which you wholy possess them who otherwise would find their saluatiō with the flock of JESUS-CHRIST; do not Imagin that it is à shame to discouer your paine to him that can cure you. Suffer your selues to be touched with Repentence, & do not any longer Refuse those Remedies which can restore you to health. For at last you must be persuaded, that of all things which à Christian can do, the most glorious, & that which one may say, is onely necessarie, is to acknowledge his Error before God.

Which if you resuse to do, after so pressing Exhortations of our part; & if you will not, nor admitt your selves to be ouercome by our prayers, nor gain'd by our tender loue, nor submitt to our advice, know that the Angels of peace will weep bitterly; yet notwithstanding wee wil neuer Abandon you to your selves the more for that, although wee have to do vvith à stubborn & stiff necked people; yet wee will still seeke in you the lambs of JESUS-CHRIST through the thornes and Bryars vvhich hinders your Reunion vvith his flock, & after vvee haue done our endeavours vvith you, & by you rejected, to Inspire you vvith the thoughts of peace, by offerring you these ready vvays of Reconciliation vvith the Church; the grace of peace vvhich vvee haue offerred unto you vvith so much sincerity & tenderness vvill return unto uss after being cast out by you, & God vvill not farther
aske nor call us to an accoumpt for your souls. & because that this last Error vvill be more Criminell in yovv then all the formers, you cannot but expect euills to fall upon you Incomparably more dreadfull then all that ever your Reuolt & schisme has brought upon you to this day. But vvee hope & expect from you our most dear Brethren better Resolutions, and more fauourable designs for your salvation. Given at Paris in the generall Assembly of the Clergie of France the first day of July & year of grace 1682.

Germains in Laye, in the said year, in taking leaue of his Majestie.

div.head: TO THE KING:
div.p: THE CLERGIE of France, that formerly approach'd not their Soveraigns, but to set forth the dolefull Jmages of an opprest & sighing Church; comes this day acknowledgeing the Joyes of their hearts demonstrateing to your Majestie, the same Church surrounded with the glorie she holds of your piety.

She has appear'd for above an age, on the brinks of her Ruine; her bowells Rent by her one Children, betray'd by those that ought to support and defend her, and made à prey to her most cruell enemies; but after à long & languishing oppression, she Respir'd à litle before your glorious birth; for with you she began to live, with you she mounted the throne, and the years of her encrease, she reckons by the years of your Reigne; & 'tis under the most flourishing Empire of the world wee see her this day more flourishing then ever.

If yet she remembers her trobles and miseries past, 'tis but the better to Relish the perfect happiness you make her enjoye; she is now free from agitation or fear under the wings of your Authority; she is also (if I dare Express it) without desires, since your zelé leaves her no time to Consider, and that your goodnesse so often surpasseth her wishes.

This ardent zelé for the faith, this fatherly goodness in all the affairs of the Church (qualities most rare in Princes) occasions GREAT SIR, the true subject of our Elogies. Wee leave your other subjects to admire the abundance of other virtues in you; some will Represent you as à well-doeing Monarch, liberall, magnificent, true to his promiss, firme and inflexible against all sorts of Injustice, upright and equitable, even to give sentencé against his proper intrests; à truly-great master of his people, but à greater master of himselfe; others will Respect you as à King always wise, and alwayes victorious, whose impenetrable design's are sooner executed, then knowne; who Reigns not onely over his subjects by his soveraigne Authority, but over his councill by the superiority of his genius, and over the courts of his neighbours, by the penetration of his witt, & his wisdome in which he is able to Instruct his ministers; who knows by himselfe to surpass the greatest of men, and without them, Resolue, undertake and Execute; who gives laws, as well by sea, as by land; who launceth when he pleaseth, his thunder, even to the borders of Afrique; who knows to humble proud nations, and reduce their soveraigns to come to the feet of his throné, acknowledging his power and imploreing his clemencie.

Your enemies them selves SIR, cannot forbear to praise your heroick actions, they are forc't to Confess, that nothing is able to Resist you; the merrit of the conquerour sweetening in some sorte the misfortune of the Conquered.

'Tis not for us GREAT SIR, to speake the Astonsihing progress of your triumphing armes, wee ought not to mixt à shineing vallour, that is but the object of admiration to men, with those holy actions Esteem'd by heaven: the Clergie SIR, Joynes in the whole
to Rejoyce in your piety, which is always attentive to the Intrests of the church, and omitts nothing that can be necessarie to Rebuild those walls that have been demolished, to the end, her extent may reach even beyond the seas, to places where she is not knowne, as it were, to make her triumph, both in the one, & the other, world.

But what do I say? the Church of her selfe ought she not to consecrate those victories, which you have so hapily apply'd to the propagation of the faith, and the extinction of heresie? it seems that you have onely fought & triumph'd but for GOD; and the fruit you gather by the peace, gives us to understand, what was the principall end of your conquests; and 'tis by those victories that you have Establish't this unquestionable power, which holds from hence-forth your neighbours by the Reines, and taketh from the hereticks of your kingdomes the Impudence to Rebell & hopes to sucseed by seditious Intrigues with the enemies of your state.

Had it been ambition, that moved you to arme; unto where, might you not have extended your empire? & do wee not knowe; that your being in haste to end the warr, even when the greatest of advantages was in your power, that 'twas nothing els, but the impresment you had to give your whole cares, to the progress of Religion, and the Conversion of so many souls engadged in Error, which of all other conquests seem'd to you the most glorious, and the triumph the most-worthy, of à King the most Christian.

But great as your puissance was, she still wanted the aide of your Goodness in winning the hearts of your Subjects in Heresie misledd, who now prostrate the obstinacie of their Spirits, to the Excellencie of your will, seeing by good works you combate the hardness of their hearts? and perhaps they could never have entred into the bosome of the Church, by any, other way then by that path spred with flowers which you have opened unto them.

It must also GREAT SIR, be acknowledged, that what Intrest wee have in the extirpation of heresie, is transported by our Joy, some thing aboue the greife wee should have, if to surmount this cloud à vexatious necessity should force your zelé, to have recourse to fier and sword, as in precedeing Reigns your Royall predecessors
have been forced to do. Wee should take parte in à holy & Just warr, and wee should also abhor it, because 'twould be cruell and sanguine; wee would offer our vow's for the sucsess of your sacred armes; but could not behold without trembling the dreadfull executions, of which the God of Revenge would make you the Instrument; however wee would mixt our voices with the publique acclamations of your victories, and in secret should lament on à triumph, that with the defeat of our enemies would be enwrap'd the loss of our brethren.

This day then, seeing you combate the pride of Heresie, but by sweetness, and discreetness of government; that your laws are maintain'd by good-deeds your onely armes; and that the advantadges you bring, are of dammadge to none but to the Demon of Revolt & of Schisme; wee have but the pure acts of thancks-giveings to render unto heaven, that inspired you, to these meeke & prudent means to vanquish all Error, and to be able by mingling à litle severity with abundance of graces & favours, to re-unite to the Church, those that are found to have been unhappily separated.

Wee confess GREAT SIR, that 'tis to your Majestie alone, wee shall soone owe the Intire r'establishment of the faith of our fathers; must it not alsoe be, that the state is already indebted to you, for her salfty & glory; the church owes, her victorie and triumph to none but to you; or otherwise to your Reign, which heaven would have to be à Reign of wonders, or elss its most fairest ornament had been wanting; it may be well said one day of your Majestie, what the Scriptures says of Divers great kings of Judea: he has Reduced his enemies & advanced the Monarchie, he has authorised and Reformed the laws, & has made Justice reign, but to them was added, the reproach which the holy ghost gave those Princes, they did not abolish the sacrafices to Idolls that was done on the tops of the mountains.
That your name GREAT SIR, may be à stranger to this Reproach, is what your zele has already done, which posterity will regard as the source of your prosperities, and the top of your glories.

'Twas not onely the r'establishment of churches and Alters, that
transported your zelé, but the undertakeing to revive devotion and good maners, forwhich your Majestie has labour'd with sucsess, as well by your example as by your orders.

'Tis now à day's honourable to practise virtues, and if vice be not altogether destroy'd, she is reduced at least to be hidd, and the vails that covers her, spares to good people à displeaseing scandale, and saves weake souls from perill & dreadfull Contagion.

Let's thinck no more of those days of darkness, when the greatest part of them that remain'd in the bosome of the Church, seemingly were not, but for outrage the most sencible, when blasphemies, and sacrelegious scoffing at all that was sacred, so impudently was boasted, by monsters of Infidelity who now disapear under your Happy Reign, and if the Remonstrances, so often reiterated upon this Subiect, do not give us suffitient kowledge of those disorders, wee shall Ignore them for ever. what's become of that other Monster produc'd by the spirit of Revenge, that was always besmer'd with the blood of men, but most of all with the blood of the french nobility; wee have but to leave it in Eternal oblivion, where long since you have plac'd it; you have vtterly stifled it, so mighty as it appear'd: you well knew, to overthrow base maxims of honour and shame; and by how much more detestable errour had given falls honour to Revenge, by so much the more Jgnominious will it be, not to obey you; and thus your will alone has overuled an inveterate custome of wickedness, and the criminall inclinations of men.

The Clergie disposes them selves now, onely to be as spectators, to behold the end of all your holy undertakeings, after haveing admired so glorious à begining; she ceases to use Remonstrances, if there may be occasion, it suficeth that you know it; in this Assembly she comes to acknowledge the signall Effects of your Royall protection, perswaded that you have design'd her à long continuance of graces & favours, in these and other times, with those circumstances, which you alone know so well to accompagnie; she would fear by demands to disturb, the order your wisdome has establish't, or perhaps to put limits, where your zelé had plac'd none.

The onely affair that takes us up, is the obligation to render to your Majesty our most humble acknowledgements; and after so Just à duty, assur'd that wee are in your powerfull protection, shall seperate our selves without the least disquiet, and goe into the severall provinces of your Realme, to offer the praises due, by the Church to your zelé, where every shepherd will reioyce to see, the number of his flock encreas'd by your cares, for which every of us will redouble his voice, to obteine from heaven, that God may redouble his blessings in favour of à Prince, that acquires them by actions so glorious, & to Religion so usefull.

div.head: THE COMPLAINT. Of the generall Assembly of the Clergie of France, against the Invective Calumnies, base Injuries, & falsities, which the Pretended Reformers have spread, and dayly publish in their boocks and Preachings, à gainst the Doctrine of the holy Catholique Church, Carried to the King by the body of the Clergie the 14th day of July 1685.
TO THE KING.
div.p:
THE CLERGIE of your Realme, has made severall complaints to your Majesty against those of the pretended Reformed Religion,
with great precaution, to include any thing but what was most needfull, and that could be most clearly proved.

But espetially she thought it her duty, to separate this one, from all the rest, it being the onely thing that grieves her above all, & that seems to her the most important, which she grounds upon proofs the most evident.

This complaint GREAT SIR; concerns the faith of the holy Catholique church, whose purity, the ministers and writers of the pretended Reformed Religion, endeavours to blacken, by most cruell Injuries, & by most falss & scandelous Calumnies.

They knew they could not attaque her by solid reason, for they found by experience, that the arguments, which they made use of when they undertooke, to prove their new Doctrine, made but à very weake impression on the minds of the people, they see dayly, that when they faithfully relate the true sence of the Catholique Church, that then they are not able, to Justifie their separation, nor excuse the excess of the first authors of their sect; and being unable to defend themselves by these means, they have recourse to a most uniust and pernitious invention, to impute to the Catholique Church an infinite number of most gros, and insufferable errors: they sopose she dissembles, or that she condemns the most essentiall truths of Religion; and represents her, under the most frightfull figure of à Church professing damnable and idolatrous doctrines, that believes not the vereties of true faith, and 'tis no wonder, they should by these means, infuse hatred, aversion & horrour of the Church, into the mindes of the people that are under their tuition.
The Clergie with greife long since beheld the dreadfull Effects of this distemper, and sought means to put a stop to it's cource.

In the last assembly of 1682. she sett forth à fatherly advertissement to the pretended Reformers upon this subject, believeing, that by pressing them to explaine the Reasons of their separation, that they would enter into themselues, and be ashamed to see, that it was grounded but upon sopositions and calumnies; & thancks be to God, that attempt was not altogether fruitless, seeing, since that time the numbers almost infinite of hereticks, that have been converted, there being but very few, that cannot but submitt themselves to this invincible argument; that as they can never have à just cause for separation, so all that the pretended Reformers aleadge, cannot have the least solidity.

But there is one obstacle that hinder'd, and that doth still hinder & put à stop to the fruit, the most considerable that was hoped for, which is, that the voice of the Bishops, and Pastors of the Catholique Church could not reach the ears of the common people of the pretended Reformed Religion; their Ministers haveing either diverted them from readeing the said advertissement, or gave them a falss explication therof, as they do of the sacred scriptures and works of the holy fathers; by which means SIR, the greatest part of your subjects of the pretended Reformed Religion, are detain'd in their Errors; and the distemper is without cure, if your Majestie do not assist by your protection, and support by your Authority what the Clergie has so happily began.

Notwithstanding, the Kings your Majesties Royall predecessors, did not permit the Excercise of the pretended Reformed Religion, but upon consideration of the troblesomness of those times, and for other Reasons, now out of dores; and that in the flourishing state, wherin your vallour & wisdome has plac'd your kingdome, the Clergie has most just cause to desire the revocation of those Edicts which conteins that permission, is at present, not the point, on which the Clergie insists.

The Request, the Clergie most humbly makes to your Majesty, is not for the Revocation of any Edict whatever; for there is none, neither can their be any that permitts the pretended reformers, to Calumniate and belie the Catholique Church, and atribute unto her falss doctrines, which she teacheth not, & which she never did believe or teach.
If fuch à liberty were, 'twould be a most unhappy priveledge, of which the ministers themselves ought to be ashamed.

Falss sopositions, detractions & Calumnies, are crimes Condemn'd by all the laws of God and man; and are punish'd with severity, although they should touch but the Reputation of some particular person, and are yet more punishable, when they are given to attaint the intire body of the state.

How blind soever the pretended Reformers may be, it cannot reach to that degree, as to dare maintaine, that such crimes and the practise of them ought to be permitted, or so much as to complaine of what your Majesty shall prohibit them to comitt.

It's notwithstanding GREAT SIR, the onely favour, the Clergie begs of
you, that dureing the time it shall please your Majesty to permitt, to the pretended Reformers, the Excercise of their Religion, that they may be defended from presumeing to continue the lies & Calumnies they have usvally spred, & which they dayly publish in their preachings and writeings.
Your Majesty will plainly see, that 'tis not without cause, the Clergie makes you this complaint.

Yet wee have forbore to Report divers of their expressions, which shakes all the order of modesty, & that Saint Paul forbids the faithfull to pronounce; your Majesty will have horrour, to see • he Incredible excess, to which the passion of the pretended reformers have transported them.
There is not an article of our faith, against which they have not comitted outrage, by most gross & Insufferable Calumnies.
The Collection wherof, which the Clergie has made and which she takes the liberty to present to your Majesty, is the conviction.

They accuse the Catholique Church of professing Errors they accuse us, of not believing, the fundamentall verities of Christianity; & to express their accusations, they serve themselves with expressions the most Insolently uncivill in the world.

The Clergie, SIR, complains, of à maner of proceeding the most unreasonable that ever was, and to shew plainly the Injustice, they humbly intreat your Majesty to compare the doctrine, which the Calvinists atribute to the Chruch of Rome, with that, which is contein'd in her profession of faith, and in the decissions of the holy Council of Trent.
This comparison is the most naturall & most sure way to Judge of the Justice, or injustice of the pretended Reformers accusations; and is onely what the Clergie desires, with Respect to your Majesty.
Wee have set downe each article of faith in particular to avoid Confusion, and for the greater clearing of the truth; and in the same designe, wee have made to each article of faith two Collum's.
In the first wee have writt the express termes of the profession of faith & decissions of the holy councill of Trent; and there your Majesty will see the true doctrine of the Catholique Church.

In the seacond wee have set forth the express words of the Pretended
Reformers in their boocks, where they expose the faith of the Church of Rome, and your Majesty will see what doctrine it is, that they impute unto us.

And by this paralell alone (then which there can be nothing more Inocent, and more sincere) your Majesty will clearly see, that they have no Resemblance to each other, but to the Contrary the differrence being so sencible & palpable, between the doctrine which the Church of Rome professeth, and that which the pretended Reformers do attribute to her, that they are manifestly convicted of base impostures and Calumnies.

If the question were but of our particular persons, wee should never appear, to bring our complaints to your Majesty, for to obteine your Justice and power for the Reparation of the Injuries that the Ministers dayly give out of us in their libells; to the contrary, the Clergie would Rejoyce, if they could wittness, by their patience and voluntarie forgiveing (the outrages they do) the sincere Charity they have for them, but wee cannot neglect the honnour of our Mother the Church, which the ministers attacques, by their Calumnies, nor the conversion & salvation of so great à number of souls which they Retaine in Errour by their false positions.

Wee doubt not SIR, by the same Considerations, but your Majesty will be most sencible who upon all occasions has shewn so much zele, for the salvation of your subjects, & so much respect and veneration for the Church, but you will also Repress by your authority, an Injustice so wicked, and so contrary, not onely to the principles of Christianity, but even to the Common rules of naturall Right.

These things GREAT SIR, considered, wee most humbly pray your Majesty first, to renew by such means as your Majesty shall please & Judge most convenient, such Edicts & Declarations, by which the pretended Reformers are order'd to speake with Respect, of the Misteries of our Religion, and to forbid them when they have à mind to propound or refute any articles of our faith, any more to make use of such Injurious & unchristian Expressions, as hetherto they have done, & which the Clergie has Collected, nor for the future to substitute the like. Seacondly, as the doctrine of the Catholique Church is clearly laid downe in her profession of faith, & in the decissions of the holy councill of Trent,
likewise to forbid them, to impute to the catholique Church, any other pretended Errors, as to this present they have had the Impudence to do, notwithstanding the Church has always detested and condemn'd them, in what authors soever such principles were found.

Yow will by this conduct GREAT SIR, imprint in the souls of all your subjects the Inviolable Respect they ought to have for Church and faith; and untill those of the pretended Reformed Religion shall be converted, they will the more freely submitt themselves to the orders of the Church, & with better inclination will follow her doctrine, whilst the enemies of her truth & glorie have not, at least the licence much longer to insuit, by their scandalous comportments.

div.head: THE DOCTRINE OF The most holy Catholique Church Contein'd in our profession of faith, and in the decrees of the holy Councill of Trent. OPPOSED To the Calumnies, lies, & falseties, spred in the vvorks of the pretended Reformers.
Fidei Professio quae habetur in fine Concilii Tridentini.
div.p:
EGO firma fide credo & profiteor omnia & singula, quae continentur in Symbolo Fidei, quo S. R. Ecclesia utitur, videlicet. CREDO in unum Deum Patrem Omnipotentem, factorem Caeli & Terrae, visibilium omnium, & invisibilium: & in unum Dominum JESUM CHRISTUM Filium
Dei unigenitum; & ex Patre natum ante omnia saecula, Deum de Deo, lumen de lumine, Deum verum de Deo vero, genitum non factum, consubstantialem Patri, per quem omnia facta sunt; qui propter nos Homines, & propter nostram salutem descendit de Coelis: Et incarnatus est de Spiritu Sancto ex Maria Virgine; ET HOMO FACTUS EST; Crucifixus etiam pro nobis sub Pontio Pilato, passus & sepultus est; & resurrexit tertia die secundum Scripturas; & ascendit in caelum sedet ad dexteram Patris; & iterum venturus est cum gloria judicare vivos & mortuos; cujus regni non erit finis; Et in Spiritum Sanctum Dominum & vivificantem; qui ex Patre Filioque procedit; qui cum Patre & Filio simul adoratur, & conglorificatur; qui locutus est per Prophetas: Et unam sanctam Catholicam & Apostolicam Ecclesiam. Confiteor unum Batisma in remissionem peccatorum; & exspecto resurrectionem mortuorum, & vitam venturi saeculi. Amen.
I Firmly believe and Confess, all and every the Articles Contein'd in the Simbole or Creed of faith, vsed in the holy Church of Rome to wit.

I believe in one God the father Almighty, maker of heaven & earth,
and of all things visible and invisible.

And in one Lord JESUS-CHRIST, the only begotten son of God, and born of the father before all ages. God of God, light of light, true God of the true God: Begotten, not made, consubstantial to the father, by whom all things were made.

Who descended from heaven, for us men, and for our salvation: and takeing flesh of the virgin Mary, by the operation of the holy Ghost, BECAME MAN. He also was Crucified for us under Pontius Pilate, suffered and was buried, and rose again the third day, according to the Scriptures.
Who ascended into heaven, and sits at the Right hand of the father, who will come again in glory, to Judge the liveing and the dead, of whose kingdome there shall be no end.
And I believe in the holy Ghost, the Lord and giver of life, who proceeds from the father and the son, who is adored and glorified Ioyntly with the father and the son, who spake by the Prophets.
I believe one holy, Catholick, and Apostolick Church. I confess one Baptisme for the Remission of sins. I expect the Resurrection of the dead, and life in the world to come. Amen. that is so be it.

div.head: ARTICLE THE FIRST. Of Scriptures Canonicall, and of Tradition.
PROFESSIO Fidei.
div.p: Apostolicas, & Ecclesiasticas Traditiones, reliquas{que} ejusdem Ecclesiae Observationes & Constitutiones firmissimè admitto & amplector. Item Sacram Scripturam juxta eum sensum, quem tenuit & tenet Sancta Mater Ecclesia, cujus est judicare de vero sensu & Interpretatione Scripturarum, admitto.

1. Concilium Trident. ses. 4. in Decreto de Canonicis Scripturis: Sancta Synodus Ortodoxorum Patrum exempla secuta, omnes libros tam veteris, quam novi Testamenti, suscipit ac veneratur: Sacrorum verò Librorum indicem huic decreto adscribendum censuit.

2. Fidei Professio: nec eam Scripturam, unquam nisi juxta.
unanimem consensum Patrum accipiam & interpretabor.

Scripturis: Necnon Traditiones ipsas, tùm ad Fidem, tùm ad mores pertinentes, tamquam vel ore tenùs à Christo, vel à Spiritu sancto dictatas & continuâ successione in Ecclesia Catholica conservatas, pari pietatis affectu ac reverentiâ suscipit ac veneratur.

div.head: THE CONTINUATION of the doctrine of the holy Catholick Church, contein'd in our profession of faith, and in the decrees of the holy Councill of Trent.
div.p:
I Receave, & imbrace most firmly the Apostolick & Eclesiastick traditions, & the other Constitutions, and observances of the Same Church. I receave the
holy Scriptures according to the sense, which our holy mother the Church holds and believes, unto whom it appertains to iudge of the true sense & interpretation of the holy Scriptures. The holy council of Trent according to the example of the orthodox fathers receaves all those books, as well of the old, as of the new testament, of which à Catalogue is placed at the End of their decrees.

2. I will never use nor interpret, those books,
But according to the unanimous consent, and oppinion of the holy fathers of the Church.

1. The holy councill receaves with the same Respect and equall devo • ion the traditions whether they concerne the faith or man̄ers, as spoaken by the mouth of JESUS CHRIST or by the holy Ghost, and which have been Reserved in the holy Catholick Church by a Continuall succession.

div.head: ARTICLE II. Of the Efficacy, number and ceremonies of the Sacraments, of pennance and auricular Confession.

Poenitentiam, Extremam-Vnctionem, Ordinem & Matrimonium.

div.head: DOCTRINE OF THE CHURCH.
div.p: I 1. Confess also that there is truly and properly seaven Sacraments of the new law, instituted by our lord JESUS-CHRIST, and necessarie to the salvation of men, although all of them are not to every one.
These Sacraments are Baptisme, Confirmation, Euchariste, Pennance, Extreame-Unction, holy Orders, & Matrimonie.
1. If any one shall say, that thêse Sacraments of the new law do not Conferr grace of them selves; but that faith a lone in the divine promisses is suffitient to obteine grace, let him be Anathema.

1. The receavers are disposed to Righteousness, when excited & assisted by the grace of God, receaveing faith by hearing, carrying them selves freely towards God, & holding for veritable, those things that have been promised & Revealed by God, & this point above all others that the sinner is justified of God by his grace, & by the Redemption acquired through JESUS-CHRIST. Then knowing them selves to be sinners.

with fear of the divine Justice, by which they are profitably stirr'd up to the Consideration of Gods mercie, & are raised into hopes, trusting that God will be mercifull unto them, for the love of JESUS CHRIST; and begin to love him as the fountain of all Justice
& therfore they are moved against sin, by a certaine hatred & detestation; that is to say by Repentance, that ought to precede Baptisme. To the end that when they Resolue to be baptised, to begin
a new life, and keep the Comandements of God.

I believe that three
of the Sacraments; to witt, Baptisme, Confirmation, & holy order, cannot be administred twice to any one body without sacriledge.

1. If any one shall deny, that Sacramentall confession, either to have been instituted, or that 'tis necessary to salvation by divine Right, or says that the manner of Confessing secretly to the Preist alone, as 'tis used in the holy Catholick Church, is not conformable to the institution, and precept of JESUS-CHRIST; but that 'tis a humane invention, let him be Anathema.

2. If any one shall say, that in the Sacrament of Repentance, it is not necessary by divine Right, for the Remission of sins, to confesse all and every mortall sin of which they can Remember, after haveing beforehand carefully examin'd themselves, even the most secret
sins, which are against the two last Comandements of the table, & the circumstances, which change the kind of sin &c. let him be Anathema.
1. I receave and admitt the Ceremonies aproved by the holy Catholick Church, in the solemn administration of all the Sacraments.

2. Et Can. 26. Si quis dixerit Iustos non debere pro bonis operibus, quae in Deo fuerint facta, exspectare, & sperare aeternam retributionem à Deo per ejus misericordiam, & Iesu Christi meritum, si benè agendo, & divina mandata custodiendo usque in finem perseveraverint, Anathema sit.

div.head: DOCTRINE OF THE CHURCH.
div.p: I 1. Receave all those points which were decided in the holy councill of Trent, concerning originall sin, & Justification.

2. If any one shall maintaine, that the sin of Adam, which is one in its source, & which is transmitted unto all by generation, & not by imitation becomes proper to every one,
may be blotted out, either by force of humane nature, or by any other means, but by the merits of JESUS-CHRIST our lord and onely mediator, who reconciled us by his blood; or whoever denies, that the same meritts of JESUS-CHRIST, are applyed, as well to those that are of age, as to Infants, by the Sacrament of Baptisme
Conferr'd according to the forme and Custome of the Church, let him be Anathema.

1. If any one denies that by the grace of our Lord JESUS-CHRIST, which is Conferr'd in Baptisme, the guilt of originall sinn: is Remitted, or hodls that all that is properly & truly of sin is not taken away; but is only as it were shaved, or is not Imputed, let him be Anathema the holy Councill neverthelesse Confesseth & acknowledgeth that.

à Concupiscence, or the Inclination to sin, remains notwithstanding in the persons Regenerated by Baptisme; but also declares, that this Concupiscence, which the Apostle sometimes calls sin was never taken, nor understood by the Catholick Church, as à reall sin.
that Remains to (speake properly) in the persons baptised; but that it has been call'd by the name of sin, because it is an Effect of sin, & that it induceth to sin.

1. If any one shall say that à man may be Iustified before God by his proper works, done onely by his naturall force, or by the lights of faith, without the grace of God merited by JESUS-CHRIST, let him be Anathema.

2. If any one shall say that without the Inspiration of the holy ghost
and without his helpe, a man may make acts of faith, of hope & Charity & Repent, such as he ought to do for to obteine the grace of Justification, let him be Anathema.
1. Wee are said to be Justified gratis; be cause in Effect nothing of all that precedes Justification, let it be faith, let it be works, do not merrit, even the grace of Justification.

1. If any one shall say, that free will moved & excited by God, by giveing his consent to God, who excited him, & who calls him, cooperat's in nothing towards prepareing himsefe, & putting him in à state to obteine the grace of Justification; & that he canot refuse his consent, if he will; but that he is like à thing without soul unable to act any thing, & only passive, let him be anathema.

2. If any one shall say that man is Justified by faith alone after the maner as is understood therby, that for to obteine the grace of Justification, there needs no other thing, to Cooperate, let him be Anathema.

3. If any one shall say that men are Justified either by the onely imputation of the
Justice of JESUS-CHRIST, or by Remission of sins only, Excludeing the grace of Charity, which is Effused in to their hearts, by the holy Ghost, let him be Anathema.
1. If any one shall say that in any good worke whatever, the Just sinneth at least venially; or even, that which is yet more insupportable, that he sins Mortally, let him be Anathema.

2. If any one shall say that the Just, for their good works done in the grace of God, ought not to expect, nor hope from him the Eternall Recompense, by his mercie, & by the meritts of JESUS-CHRIST, provided he perseveres in doing well to the End, & in keeping his Comandements, let him be Anathema.

div.head: CALUMNIES OF THE PRETENDED REFORMED.
ARTICLE IV. Of the adoration of JESUS-CHRIST in the Euchariste, & of the Mass.

div.p: 1. Professio Fidei: Profiteor pariter in Missa eff • rri Deo verum. proprium & propitiatorium Sacrificium pro vivis & defunctis.

2. Conc. Trid. sess. 22. cap. 1. Sacrificium, quo cruentum illud semel in cruce peragendum repraesentaretur, ejusque memoria in finem usque saeculi permaneret, atque
illius salutaris virtus in remissionem eorum, quae à nobis quotidie committuntur, peccatorum applicaretur.

1. Professio Fidei: Atque in sanctissimo Eucharistiae Sacramento esse verè realiter & substantialiter corpus & sanguinem unâ cum animâ & Divinitate Domini nostri Iesu Christi: fierique conversionem totius substantiae panis in corpus & totius
substantiae vini in sanguinem, quam conversionem Catholica Ecclesia transsubstantiationem appellat: fateor etiam sub altera tantùm specie, totum atque integrum Christum, verumque Sacramentum sumi.

1. Conc. Trid. sess. 13. Can. 6. Si quis dixerit in Eucharistiae Sacramento Christum unigenitum Filium Dei, non esse cultu latriae etiam externo adorandum &c.
Idololatras, Anathema sit.

div.head: DOCTRINE OF THE CHURCH.
div.p: I 1. Confess that in the holy mass, is offerr'd to God, one true, proper, & propitiatory Sacrifice for the liveing, & for the dead.

2. A Sacrifice which Represents unto us the Bloody Sacrifice of JESUS-CHRIST upon the Cross, Conserveing in us the memory therof, and applys unto us, a whole some virtue for the
Remission of the sin̄s wee dayly comit.

1. I believe that the body & Blood with the soul and Divinity of JESUS-CHRIST are truly, really & substantially Contein'd in the most holy Sacrament of the Euchariste; & that there is made a Changement of the whole substance of bread in to the body, & of the whole substance of the wine,
into the Blood; is that which the Catholick Church calls Transubstantiation. I confess, that in each of both kinds, is receaved the whole body & blood of JESUS-CHRIST & the true Sacrament.

1. If any one shall say that JESUS-CHRIST only son of God, ought not to be adored in the holy Sacrament of the Euchariste, with divine worship, even Exteriourly, & that those, that adore him
are Jdolaters, let him be Anathema.

div.head: CALUMNIES OF THE PRETENDED REFORMED.
div.p:
THat Thesaurus Disputat. Sedan. de Sacramento Eucharistiae parte. 2. th. 40. tom. 1. pag. 810. Tenentur violatae Religionis & depravati Evangelii, qui nobis ex humano cerebro procuderunt novum Sacerdotium cujus Christus non est Autor, &c. Et in thesi 12. de Missa & Transsubstantione pag. 825. ejusdem tom. 1. Tenetur Ecclesia Romana violatae Religionis, quae novum Sacerdotium & Sacrificium instituerit, absque ullo Dei mandato, per Sacrificium Sacrificulus Christo anteponitur. wee have forged a new Preisthood, of which JESUS-CHRIST is not the author, & an other sacrifice, besides that of his death, in which wee place the Preist above JESUS-CHRIST; that Ibidem th. 34. pag. 828. Eo procedit superstitio, ut Sacerdos dicat se Christum offere Deo in honorem Sanctorum, quae oratio Sanctos supra Christum evehit. in the sacrifice of the Mass, wee Raise the Saints in Celebrateing their memoires above JESUS-CHRIST
that Catechismus Heydelbergensis quaest. 80. referente & laudante Francisco Burmanno in Synopsi Theologica l. 7. c. 15. §. 31. tom. 2 pag. 414. Missae Sacrificium nihil aliud est, quam abnegatio unici illius Sacrificii & Passionis Iesu Christi & execranda Idololatria. Addit ipse Bu • mannus. Specie enim sacrificii Christi, Patri quotidiè offerendi, excogitatum hic fuit diaboli astu sacrificium falsum & idololatricum, unicè comparatum ad abolendum verum Christi sacrificium & extirpandam omnem ejus vim & memoriam. Joannes VVollebius Theologiae Professor Basileensis in compendio Doctrinae Christianae l. 1. c. 18. §. 22. pag. 103. Edit. Amstelodamensis an. 1655. Evertunt eamdem Christi satisfactionem Papani, alios Sacerdotes constituentes, & Missam Idololatricam pro sacrificio obtrudentes. the Sacrifice of the Mass is a renouncement to that of the Cross; & to the fruit of the death & Passion of JESUS-CHRIST; that it destroys & overthrows it by a sacrilegious Attempt; that Guilielmus Bucanus loco 48. §. 145, pag. 798. Pontificiorum errores, qui Missae nomen à sacris Isiais sunt mutuati, &c. Verba coenae Dominicae, in Ephesias Litteras transformant, seu in consecrationem talem quae nihil dissert ab incantationibus magi • is, &c. pag. 799. Ibidem Qua ratione sacrificium Crucis Christi prorsùs evacuatur, unicum & perpetuum ejus Sacerdotium negatur, mortis ejus meritum obruitur, Chrstus rursus occiditur. Synopsis purioris Theologiae Professorum Lugdunensium apud Batavos disp. 46. th. 1. pag. 698. Pontificii loco Coenae à Christo institutae, nobis Missam obtrudunt; haec Sacramentum impietatis, signum Apostasiae, ac vinculum dissentionis appellari potest. wee have borrowed the name of Mass from the sacrifices of the Godesse Isis; & that in this Sacrifice, wee put JESUS-CHRIST againe to Death; that the Consecration which wee do
differs nothing from the enchantments of Magick; & that one may call the Mass the Sacrament of ungodlinesse, the signe of Apostasie; & the chaine of dissention; that Guilielmus Bucanus loco mox laud. pag. 800. Scenico & histrionico ornatu, gestu, beatu, murmure, sibilis, gemitibus, cantu & aliis modis, tanquàm Orgia Sacra & Bacchanalia celebrant, &c. wee celebrate the Mass like the orgies & the Bacchanalias or feasts of the Pagans; that Georgius Dounamus in libro cui titulus est Papa Antichristus, l. 3. c. 7. pag. 20 • . Missas etiam celebrant, hoc est Christum ipsum Deo offerunt, in honorem Sanctorum, pro illorum intercessione apud Deum obtinenda. in the Mass wee offer JESUS-CHRIST to God in the hōnour of the Saints, for to obteine by him their intercession with God; that Franciscus Burmannus in Synopsi Theologica l. 7. c. 15. §. 25. tom. 2. pag. 412. Sacramentum hoc in Idolum in Ecclesia erexerunt, qui summus erroris gradus est, ita ut panis ipsorum ven • num sit, cùm non manducetur solùm; sed & adoretur. Et §. 28. eadem pag. Nos autem h • c pacto Sacrilegio & Id • l • latriâ contaminari Ecclesiam, Deumque novum invehi, & furfura •• um denique numen coli contendimus. Theodorus Beza in Antithesi Paparus & Christianissimi tom. 1. tractat. Theologic. pag. 64. Ita fit ut miseri Papistae, ex ipsorum placitis vel sint Id • lolatrae, panis enim adorationem, vel ipsi quidem non inficiabuntur esse Id l • lat • iam, vel non nisi sub conditione, si fortè a • fa rit▪ furf • raceum illud suum numen possint adorare. Franciscus Burmannus mox laudatus eodem l. & capite, §. 29. pag. 413. tom. 2. Adorant aliquid, quod Christus non est; sed Idolum. wee
adore a God of meale; that Georgius Dounamus in L. cui titulus est: Papa Antichristus, l 3. c. 6. pag. 180. Sicut Nestoriani Christum Hominem adorant, non quod Deus sit; sed quia Deo conjunctus; atque ita creaturam pro Creatore adorant; sic Pontificii latriae cultum, qui soli Deo debetur Sacramento Eucharistiae exibent, non quod Deus sit; sed quod Deum in eo adesse credant. Joannes Calvinus in Epist. ad D. N. S. D. pag. 95. secundae Partis Voluminis Institutionum ult. Edit. Amstelodam. Quam bellè Missae conveniat cum Coena Domini &c. cumulus autem abominationis, ipsa, quae ibi primas tenet, elementi adoratio est. wee renew the Error of the nestorians, adoreing for JESUS-CHRIST that which is not Iesus-Christ, but a bit of Bread.

div.head: ARTICLE THE V. Of satisfaction, of Purgatorie, and of Jndulgencies.

div.p:
1. Conc. Trid. sess. 14. cap. 8. Quoad satisfactionem sancta Synodus declarat falsum omninò esse & à verbo Dei alienum,
culpam à Domino nunquàm remitti, quin universa etiam poena condon etur.

1. Ibidem Neque verò ita nostra est satisfactio haec quam pro peccatis nostris exsolvimus, ut non sit per Christum Iesum; nam qui ex nobis, tanquàm
ex nobis nihil possumus, eo cooperante, qui nos confortat omnia possumus, ita non habet homo undè glorietur: sed omnis gloriatio nostra in Christo est, in quo vivimus, in quo meremur, in quo satisfacimus facientes fructus dignos poenitentiae, qui ex illo vim habent, ab illo efferuntur Patri, & per illum acceptantur à Patre.
1. Professio Fidei: Constanter teneo Purgatorium esse, animasque ibi detentas Fidelium suffragiis adjuvari.

1. Conc. Trid. sess. 25. in decreto de Purgatorio: Praecipit S. Synodus Episcopis, ut sanam de Purgatorio Doctrinam à sanctis Patribus & sacris Conciliis traditam à Christi fidelibus teneri, doceri, & ubique praedicari diligenter studeant.
1. Professio Fidei: Indulgentiarum etiam potestatem à Christo in Ecclesia relictam fuisse.
2. Conc. Trid. sess. 25. in Decreto de Indulgentiis. Atque hujusmodi potestate divinitùs sibi tradita, antiquissimis etiam temporibus Ecclesia usa fuerit.
3. Professio Fidei: Illarumque usum Christiano populo maximè salutarem affirmo.
4. Conc. Trid. in eodem Decreto de Indulg. In his tamen contedendis, moderationem juxta veterem & probatam in Ecclesia consuetudinem adhiberi cupit.

div.head: DOCTRINE OF THE CHURCH.
div.p:
AS to satisfaction, the holy Councill declares, that it is
entirely falls and farr from the word of God, to say that the sin is never forgiven by our Lord, but the paine due for the same is also Remitted.

1. But this satisfaction by which wee pay for our sins, is not so much ours, as it is done and accomplished by
JESUS-CHRIST for wee, of our selves, in as much as of us, can do nothing, but wee can do all with the assistance of him that strengthneth us, So that man has nothing wherin he may glorifie; but all the subiect of our glory is in JESUS-CHRIST, in whom wee live, in whom wee merit, & in whom wee make satisfaction, working true fruits of Repentance, which have their force and their meritt from him,
and which are offer'd by him to the father, & by his intermission they are receaved & approved of the father.
1. I firmly hold, that there is a Purgatorie, and that the souls of the faithfull, which are there detain'd, are helped by the suffrages & prayers of the faithfull.

1. The holy Councill of Trent gives orders to Bishops, that they may have a particular care, that the faith & beliefe of the faithfull, touching purgatorie, may be Conformable to the holy doctrine which was left unto us by the holy fathers, & by the Councills, & that it may be every where preached unto them & taught after the same manner.
1. I hold that the power of Indulgencies, was left by JESUS-CHRIST to the Church.
2. That she has used them since the primitive times.
3. That there use is most wholsome to the Christian People.
4. And that according to the desire of the holy councill, they ought to be granted with moderation, according to the antient & approved Custome in the Church.

div.head: CALUMNIES OF THE PRETENDED REFORMED.
div.p:
THat Franciscus Burmannus in Synopsi Theologica, l. 6. c. 9. §. 38. tom 2. pag. 258. Satisfactio merum est figmentum infandae superbiae plenum & Christi Redemptioni adversum. Thesaurus disputat. Sedanens. th. 6. de Satisfactionibus tom. 1. pag. 595. Savissima omnium satisfactio illa est, quam Purgatorium vocant, voce quidem barbara; sed sensu magis incongruo & in Christum contumelioso. Synopsis purioris Theologiae disputat. 39. thesi 21. pag. 545. Aliquas esse satisfactiones pro peccato praeter satisfactionem Christi, dogma absurdum & blasphemum est. our Doctrine Concerning satisfaction & Purgatorie is
full of vanity & pride, and injurious to Iesus-Christ; that it Thesaurus disputat. Sedanens. th. 7. de Satisfact. tom. 1. pag. 595. Cùm pro tota poena Christus abundè satisfecerit, alienum planè est à justitia Dei, pro uno eodem que debito geminam exigere solutionem. Ioannes Calvinus l. 3. Institut. c. 5. paragr. 6. pag. 175. Clamandum non modo votis, sed gutturis ac laterum contentione Purgatorium exitiale Sathanae esse commentum, quod Christi crucem evacuat, quod contumiliam Dei misericordiae non ferendam irrogat, &c. Superest Purgatorium meram esse eamque horribilem in Christum blasphemiam. The Confession of faith of the Pretended Reformed of France art, 24. wee hold Purgatorie to be an Illusion proceeding from the shop of the Divill. makes God unjust, & that it is an Invention proceeding from the shop of sathan; that Joannes Calvinus ubi mox suprà. Thesaurus disputat Sedan. th. 5. de Satisfactionibus tom. 1. pag. 595. Iejunia, peregrinationes, mulctas pecuniarias sub obtentis Paenitentiae, & flagellationis laconicae 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Imitamentum vocant opera satisfactoria, his tricis putant Deo satisfieri pro poena temporali. Et thesi 16. pag. 597. Praesto est perfectissima Christi satisfactio, cui adjungere sublasta quaedam opera, gerrasque siculas, flagellationem & ciborum distinctionem, tùm incubare solo & cranium habere pro cervicali, & sub interula modo succingi, qui lumbo exulceret, cedit in Christi contumeliam. Mox: Sanè haec ad Lydium Verbi Dei lapidem explorata, tantùm abest ut satisfaciant Deo, ut etiam poenam mereantur, & ad lancem judicii divini ponderata, immensum quantùm peccata novo pondere pragravent. all the fasts & all the mortifications of the flesh, do but cover Iesus-Christ with affronts; & that far from being able to employ them to please God, they load us with
new crimes; that Ibidem th. 24. pag. 598. Nititur hoc dogma illo axiomate, quo vix ulla est capitalior Doctrina, Christum morte sua nos liberasse à poenà & culpâ peccatorum, quae antecedum Baptismum; at pro poenis peccatorum, quae fiunt post Baptismum, Christum aut non satisfecisse, aut satisfactionem ejus nobis non imputari. Ioannes Calvinus l. 3. Institut. c. 5. paragr. 2. pag. 574. Quí poterat foedius profanari Christi Sanguis, quàm dùm negatur sufficere ad peccatorum remissionem, ad reconciliationem, ad satisfactionem, nisi velut arescentis & exhausti defectus aliundè suppleatur & sufficiatur. our doctrine concerning fatisfaction, is grounded upon this that IESUS-CHRIST has not made satisfaction, but for the sin comitted before baptisme; & denies the sufficiency of the saviour of the world; that Philippus Melancton in respons. ad articulos Bavaricos, ad art. 19. tom. 1. operum fol. 367 Apparet hos ritus (satisfactionum) à vetustate Ethnica sumptos fuisse: nam apud Ethnicos homicidae gerebant signa reatus, ut agnoscerentur ab aliis & vitarentur tamquàm pollu • i, nec cum eis mensae & convictus societas esset, ut Orestes queritur se vagatum esse, nec receptum ad aliorum mensas. Ioannes Calvinus l. 3. Institut. c. 5. paragr. 6. pag. 575. Cum ex multis blasphemiis Purgatorium constructum sit & novis quotidie fulciatur. the begining of our satisfactions proceeds from the customes of Pagans, & that it is not upheld, but by many Blasphemies; that Thesaurus disputat. Sedan. th. 9. de satisfactionibus, tom. 1. pag. 600. Hane compensationem Pontificii dicunt, fieri ex condigno, id est, per aequipollentiam. Theodorus Beza in Antithesi Papatus & Christianismi tract. Thologic. tom. 1. pag. 61. Putarunt Papistae se posse quadam compensatione satisfacere divinae justitiae, quâ in re planè ac perspicuè, se potius stupidos simul ac intolerabili arrogantiâ praeditos declararunt. wee maintaine, that by our satisfactions, wee
pay God with an equall value; that Thesaurus disputat. Sedan. th. 26. de Satisfact. tom. 1. pag. 598. Hoc est certissimum au • upium per quod ipsa mors Pontificii vectigalis est. estque jam ab aliquot saeculis lucrosa haec nundinatio. Uldaricus Zuinglius in respons. ad Valentinum tom. 1. operum fol. 263. Impiorum Sacerdotum avaritia, Christi clarissima verba in alienum sensum violenter detorsit, ut Purgatorium suum, quo non alius quaeslus illis fuit uberior, possent deffendere, quibus in conficta majorum nostrorum miseria, luxus & libidinis suae alimentum, & gaudii laetitiaeque occasionem, quaerere licuit. Ioannes Calvinus in Antidoto Conc. Trid. ad can, 30. sess. 6. opuscus. pag. 253. Nisi forte instar Vaticinii accipi volunt suum de Purgatorio commentum, quod à ventriloquis procedit, Nullum enim est, quod ad refarciendos eorum ventres, aeque valeat. Theodorus Beza in Antithesi Papatus & Christianismi in tract Theolog. tom. 1. pag, 58. Ignis Purgatorius ad purgandas potiùs crumenas, quàm anin as exstructus est Thesaurus disputat. Sedanens. tom. 2. pag. 350. th. 4. de commentitiis peccati poenis, &c. Ad fastum & quaestum excogitatas esse poenas Purgatorii, ad quastum, siquidem animae hujus ignis terrore perculsae, sacrificulis absorbendas ettam aedes tradiderunt, ut ab hisce cruciatibus immunitatem obtinerent, ideò curam suffragiorum pro defunctis persolvendorum sollicite imperant. Burnet in his Remarks upon the acts of the last generall Assembly of the Clergie of France: The Church of Rome has gain'd more by Purgatorie, then spain has done by the discovery of the new world. Purgatorie is an invention to get money; that according our Doctrine, the Pope draws tribute from the dead; thatThesaurus disputat. Sedanens. th. 22. de Satisfact. humanis tom. 1. pag. 598. Papalibus Indulgentiis vis tribuitur (eruendi à flammis Purgatorii) quae Christo negatur. wee give to Indulgencies the power to Redeem souls from Purgatorie, which wee Refuse to Iesus-Christ; that Idem Thesaurus disputat. Sedanens. th. 58. de Satisfact. parte 2. tom. 1. pag. 612. Gravissimum est quod per impium hoc dogma Deus detruditur solio, & Papa supra Deum extollitur: oportet major sit Deo, qui liberat hominem necessitate parendi Dei mandatis Peter du Moulin, Minister of Charenton, in his Buckler of faith sect. 89. Edit. of Geneva of the year 1660. pag. 344. The Pope would have us believe that he Redeems from Purgatorie; in which he manifestly puts himselfe above God. by this Doctrine the Pope deposeth
God of his throne, and Raiseth himselfe above him; that Thesaurus disputat. Sedanens. th. 13. de Satisfact. parte 2. tom. 1. pag. 612. Portenta haec sunt (Indulgentiae) & nova dogmata conflata ad incudem avaritiae. His artibus Religio Christiana vertitur in foedam caupanationem. Et antea th. 19 de Satisfact. parte 1. tom. 1. pag. 602. Ad calcem Bullae: Datum Romae; cùm potiùs scribendum fuisset venditum Romae. Andraeas Rivetus in Catholico Orthodoxo, seu summa Controvers. tractat. 3. quaest. 13. §. 8. tom. 2. pag. 97. Quamvis Indulgentiariis vendendi verbum displicere videatur, nihil tamen aliud intelligunt per causas justas, sine quibus Indulgentiae nullius sunt fructus. Ibidem vocat eas: Fictas Indulgentias. the Pope sells Jndulgences, & drives a shamefull trade on't; that Peter du Moulin in Hyperaspiste l. 1. c. 40. pag. 300. Edit Genevens. an 1636. Papa indulget & remittit peccata Deo invito, & hanc Papae Indulgentiam valere & ratam esse, quamquàm Deo, non probante piè credendum est. Prefecto hi homines suis absolutionibus & Indulgentiis se suprà Deum efferunt; sedent enim judices in Dei causà. wee believe, that the Pope forgives sins against the will of God; & that, the Indulgencies which he grants are efficacious, although God do not approve them; that by Joannes Calvinus Institut. l. 3. c. 5. §. 5. pag. 175. Porrò ut tales abominationes praetereamus, quis docuit Papam plumbo & membranâ, gratiam Iesu-Christi includere. Indulgences the Pope Binds the grace of JESUS CHRIST to parchment
and lead; that Idem Joannes Calvinus in Epistola adversus Pseudo Nicodemitas opusculorum pag. 414. Quid diplomata illa quorum te gratiam appetere simulas? An non edita voce clamant, ut nummis relictis, plenas anathemate, atque omni execratione dignas Indulgentias tibi auferas, &c. atqui eorum latebras si excussertis, nusquàm prolixius, quàm illic Christum irriaeri cum sua cruce reperies. nothing can be more to the derision of the cross of JESUS-CHRIST, then Indulgences.

div.head: ARTICLE VI. Of the Invocation of Saints, of Relicks, & of Images.

div.p:
1. Conc. Trid. sess. 25. Decreto de Invocat. Sanctor. Sanctos una cum Christo regnantes, orationes suas pro hominibus Deo offerre bonum atque utile esse suppliciter cos invocare, & ob beneficia impetranda à Deo per Filium ejus Iesum Christum,
Dominum nostrum, qui solus noster Redemptor & Salvator est ad eorum orationes, opem, auxiliumque confugere: illos verò qui negant Sanctos aeterna felicitate in coelo fruentes, invocandos esse, aut qui asserunt vel illos pro hominibus non orare, vel eorum, ut pro nobis etiam singulis orent, invocationem esse idolatriam,
vel pugnare cum verbo Dei, adversarique hono
•• unius mediatoris Dei & hominum Iesu Christi, vel stultum esse in coelo regnantibus, voce vel mente suplicare, impiè sentire. Sanctorum quoque Martyrum &
