div.head: DOCTRINE OF THE CHURCH.
div.p:
THe holy Councill teacheth, that the Saints, who Reigne with JESUS-CHRIST, offer prayers to God for men; that it is a good & profitable thing to invocate them,
& to humbly supplicate, & to have recours to their assistance, for to obteine graces & favours of God by his son, who is our onely Redeemer, & our saviour; & that those who denie that the Saints, who enioye in heaven an Eternall felicity, are to be invocated;
or who hold, that the Saints do not pray to God for men; or that 'tis Idolatry to invocate them, to the end that they should pray even for every one of us in particular; or that it is a thing which is contrary to the word of God,
& that 'tis against the honnour due to JESUS-CHRIST, alone & only Mediator between God & Men; or even that 'tis a miere folly to pray by word, or thought to the Saints who Reign in heaven, have oppinions contrarie to true piety.

1. That the faithfull ought likewise to bear
Respect to the bodys of holy Martyrs, & of other Saints who live with JESUS-CHRIST; those bodys haveing been heartofore liveing members of JESUS-CHRIST, & the temple of the holy Ghost, & will one day Resussitate to Eternall life.

1. That wee ought to have and Retaine principally in churches, the Images of JESUS-CHRIST,
the virgin Mother of God, & of other saints, & that the honnour and venerations is to be given, which is due unto them; not that wee believe, that there is in them any divinity, or any virtue, for which wee ought to give this worship, or that wee should aske any thing of them, or put any trust in them, as the Pagans did who put their hopes in their Idolls; but
because that the honour which is done unto them is Referr'd to the originals, whom they Represent.

div.head: DOCTRINE OF THE CHURCH.
div.p:

Prooemiali de Haeresibus tom. 1 pag. 42. Liquet appositissime quosdam Papismum comparasse mari mango, in quod que madmodum flumina omnia & rivi decidunt pleno alveo; sic etiam plurimae & pene omnes variorum temporum, locorum & personarum haereses in hunc errorum abyssum fluunt, & impuris ejus undis miscentur. Papisme is most Justly compared to a great sea, because it comprehends almost all sorts of heresies that ever was, as the sea Doth the Rivers; that Papisme is as far from Christianisme, as Theodorus Beza in Antithesi Papatus & Christianismi tractar. theologic. tom. 1. pag. 56. Read & approved in the General Assembly of the Clergie of France held at Saint Germains in Laye, by permission of the King, on wednesday the 11th of July & signed on saturday the 14th of same Month 1685. By the Clergie before named from pag. 14. to. pag. 16.

div.head: THE EDICT OF THE KING, Which defends the Ministers & all others of the P. R. R. to Preach, or compose books, stuff'd vvith lies and Calumnies against the Doctrine of the Church, nor to make use of termes tending to Calumnie, by imputeing Doctrines to Catholicks, vvhich they condemn &c.
div.p:
LOUIS BY THE GRACE OF GOD, OF FRANCE AND NAVARRE KING; To all present & to come, GREETING. The deputed of the Clergie of our kingdome by our permision assembled at our Citty of Saint Germains in Laye, haveing Represented unto us, that amongst other means, of which the Ministers of the P. R. R. do make use, to hinder the conversion of divers of our subjects who make profession of that Religion, there is none succeeds with so much success as that of giveing by impostures a false Idea of the Catholick Religion to the people; & haveing humbly pray'd us at the same time to prevent the continuation of so great an Evill, by such means as wee should thinck most convenient; wee have Examin'd the errors which the Ministers & others of the P. R. R. do impute to the Catholick Religion in their sermons & books. Which they compose, & as nothing so much wounds the Respect, with which our Edicts oblidges them to speak of the Catholick Religion, as to accuse our Church of professing a Doctrine
which she Condemns, & that it is not just to suffer that their Calumnies should infuse into our subjects à horrour of the truth, which they could not but love & follow if they were not deprived of the knowledge therof by such deceitfull means; & haveing otherwise consider'd, that it ought to suffice the Ministers of à Religion onely tollerated in our kingdome by the Edicts of the kings our predecessors & by our one, to teach their doctrine, without somenting Callumnies against the true Religion of which wee make profession, & from which their predecessors did in the last age unhappily seperate: wee therfore have thought it necessarie to put à stop to the course of such à liberty, which has produced such dreadfull Effects. MAKEING KNOWNE, that for these and other causes us therunto moveing, & of our Certaine knowledge, full power & Royall authority, wee have by this present Edict defended & do hearby defend all Ministers & others of what quality or Condition soever they be, professing the Pretended Reformed Religion, to Preach or compose any books against the faith & Doctrine of the holy Catholick, Apostolick & Roman Religion; or to supply themselves with Injurious termes tending to Callumnie, by imputeing Doctrines to Catholicks which they condemn, or to speak directly or indirectly without Respect in any maner whatever of the Catholick Religion. Wee enjoyne the Ministers to teach in their sermons only the Doctrine of the pretended Reformed Religion, & the rules of Morality, without touching any thing elss. Wee further forbid the Ministers, & all others our subjects who make profession of the said P. R. R. to cause to be printed any book or books concerning Religion, except such as conteine their profession of faith their prayers & the ordinarie rules of their discipline, & to all Printers & book sellers to print or sell them: wee will, that all such books as have been made to this houre against the Catholick Religion by those of the P. R. R. be supprest, wee forbid all printers to print them & all stationers to sell them for the future. Wee will & comand that the Ministers & our other subjects, of the P. R. R. who shall transgress against this our present Edict,
be condemn'd to pay an honourable fine, & for ever Banished out of our kingdome, & their goods subject to Confiscation confiscated, & the Excercise of that Religion forever prohibited in those places where the Ministers shall preach against the intent of this our present Edict. Wee will likewise that all printers & Book-sellers, who shall print or sell the said books to the prejudice of this present Edict, be condemn'd to pay 1500. Livres fine & forever made uncapable to keep open shop. So GIVEING BY COMAND to our beloued & Loyall subjects, holding our court of Parliament at Paris, that they cause this present Edict to be read, published & Registred, & the contents therin contein'd, to keep & observe according its forme & tenour, without transgressing or suffering the same to be transgressed in any sorte or manner whatsoever, for such is our will & pleasure, & to the end it may be made firme and stable for ever, wee have caused our seal to be put to these presents. GIUEN at Versailles in the month of August, & year of grace one thousand six hundred Eighty five, & of our Reigne the three & fortieth. Signed LOUIS. & upon the fold: By the King, Colbert, & sealed with the great seale of green wax, on labels of Red & green silk.

div.head: APPROBATIO.
div.p:
CUM nihil sit in omnibus rerum humanarum negotiis cuivis homini, de Salute suâ vel minimum soliciti, antiquiùs, quam ut de Religione sua fiat certior; nihil est etiam publico commodo necessarium magis, quam de Religione pro communi bono libros componere, ut verá à falsis Secretâ & notâ, Beatitudinis extremae spes in tuto posita sit. Hoc multis ab annis clerum Gallicanum occupare nemo est qui nesciat; &
in his novissimis temporibus quisque potest experiri, quid, horum comitiorum, quae invictissimo Galliarum Rege LUDOVICO XIV. convocante & protegente, pro rerum Ecclesiaticorum restauratione celebrantur, zelus, Scientia, pietas & sufficientia valeant. Regna mirantur, & obstupestunt vniversi fines terrae, cum eis annuntiatur Galliae fides. Celebrari igitur debet omnibus linguis illa natio, per quam diffamatur, ut ait Apostolus, sermo Domini, nec ullo idiomate non dicendum, quid his temporibus, pro extirpandis haeresibus foeliciter susceperit, & foelicius absolverit. Fecit hoc, qui fideliter Anglis idiomate Britannico, postrema Galliae comitiorum acta transtulit de Gallico, quorum titulum sic exprimi vidimus The proceedings of the Generall assembly of the Clergie of France. Vix pro nostro tenui hujus linguae usu de hac traductione ferre judicium arbitrabamur, sed adducto in dubiis, hominum hac in reperitorum, & ex Angliâ oriundorum, judicio, nobis prorsus fuit satisfactum, & in hoc libro nihil invenimus, quod ortodoxae fidei, & Originali non Concordaret. Datum Insulis die Februarij 28. anni 1686.
